newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian crudes steady, Tapis hits $1.15 premium.
newsitem.headline: Asian crudes steady, Tapis hits $1.15 premium.

text.p: Crude prices in Asia were steady on Monday with November Tapis hitting a premium of $1.15 and Oman showing a steadier tone.
Traders said Oman traded at various levels on Friday between MPM less one cent and four cents and firmed to trade flat on Monday between a European major and a China buyer.
Over the weekend Oman set the September selling price at $21.20, representing a 78-cent premium over the Dubai September assessment and in line with expectations.
Traders said the official price better reflected Oman's value in relation to Dubai.
But it still faced stiff competition from good supply of Masila crude.

Bangchak bought 600,000 barrels of November Tapis at a premium over benchmark quotes of $1.15 after closing a tender for November crude last week. Traders said the refiner did not take any crudes in the tender by the validity deadline last Thursday.
The Brent/Dubai for December was a steady $2.15/$2.27 implying a November Brent/Dubai at $2.27/$2.39.
Traders said a paper box trade was carried out late Friday, giving a December Brent/Dubai value of $2.26.
The box involved two European majors, a trader and a U.S. refiner.
Dubai intermonth spreads were steady with bids 42, 41 and 41 for near month spreads. November paper Tapis was bid at $23.95, up 10 cents.
A European major sold 500,000 barrels of November Murban at around ADNOC plus 34 cents -- the last of the month.
